Yes, absolutely. Here are some of the key initiatives by WHO to improve maternal and child health in developing countries:

1. Integrated Management of Childhood Illness (IMCI): This is an initiative that aims to improve the quality of care for sick children under five years of age, particularly in developing countries. The IMCI strategy includes a package of interventions to prevent, diagnose, and treat the most common childhood illnesses, such as malaria, pneumonia, and malnutrition.

2. Safe Motherhood Initiative: This initiative aims to reduce maternal morbidity and mortality by promoting access to quality maternal health services, including antenatal care, skilled birth attendants, emergency obstetric care, and family planning.

3. Breastfeeding: WHO recommends exclusive breastfeeding for the first six months of life, followed by continued breastfeeding along with the introduction of complementary foods up to two years of age and beyond. Through its Baby-friendly Hospital Initiative and Global Strategy for Infant and Young Child Feeding, WHO has worked to promote and support optimal breastfeeding practices worldwide.

4. Vaccination: Vaccination is a critical intervention to protect children from preventable diseases such as measles, polio, and pneumococcal disease. WHO works to ensure that children in developing countries have access to life-saving vaccines through initiatives such as the Expanded Programme on Immunization (EPI).

5. Accelerated Action for the Health of Adolescents (AA-HA!): This initiative aims to promote the health and well-being of adolescents, particularly in developing countries. AA-HA! focuses on areas such as creating supportive environments, improving access to health services, and promoting gender equality.

Overall, these initiatives by the WHO have played a critical role in improving maternal and child health in developing countries, promoting access to essential health services, and reducing mortality and morbidity rates.
